comment._content: Compton Mackenzie was tried for breaching the Official Secrets Act in 1933. www.spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk/Jmackenzie.htm and en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compton_Mackenzie#Other_work Some questions were raised in the Commons about the case. It appears the accused was kept in the Tower: hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1933/feb/21/official-...

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
The following summary from reports in the Times (London):

Inspector Edward M O'Connell of the Crimes Branch of the Civil Guard and Colonel Michael Hogan of The Free State Army  were charged with offences under the Official Secrets Act.. O'Connell is alleged to have communicated certain documents to Hogan, who had no authority to receive them. 

Preliminary hearings took place in February at the Dublin District Court (reported Feb 20th and 27th 1933). 

The full trial took place at The Central Criminal Court Dublin at the end of March (reported on March 28th, 30th and 31st 1933) . It appears that the documents were intended for Hogan's brother, James Hogan, Professor of Irish and History at University College, Cork, who was writing a book about communism. It transpired that Prof Hogan had permission from his brother's superior officer Col Neligan to use the documents, but Neligan had been moved on in the meantime.

Both men were acquitted, and the judge recommended that the defence costs should be paid by the government.

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content:
There is another man hiding behind the window.

I don't care what anyone says, I'm totally ignoring evidence, history and logic, and making up my own story about a complicated plot involving German spies.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: This just in from the Irish Independent on Monday, 20 February 1933: "Col. Michael Hogan, Portobello Barracks, Dublin, brother of Mr. P. Hogan, ex-Minister for Agriculture, and Detective-Inspector Edward M. O'Connell, of the Crimes Branch of the Garda Siochana, Dublin, again appeared before Mr. Cussen, D.J., in the Dublin District Court on Saturday morning, and were remanded until 11.30 a.m. next Saturday. The Attorney-General (Mr. Conor Maguire) opposed the granting of bail, but Mr. Cussen fixed bail for Col. Hogan at £1,000, with two sureties of £500 each, Detective-Inspector O'Connell being remanded in custody. The accused were charged with breaches of the Official Secrets Act, 1911, larceny of State documents, and conspiracy to steal State documents. Great public interest was taken in the case, the Court being crowded."
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: This photograph was almost certainly taken outside the Prison Sergt.'s Office in the Bridewell Garda Station where the two uniformed members of the DMG are chatting with two G Men or Branch men.  You will note the "duty band" on the Garda's right sleeve?  These were worn when on duty and the absence was a signal to civilians when the Garda was off duty.  Inside that window all prisoners were processed before being returned from courts and the daily prison van brought prisoners on remand to wait before appearing in court and back again in the evening.  Brendan Behan attacked the van on one occasion when he was in the IRA. Officers would gather in the prison Sergt.s office to chat and to check up on remands et.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/morris_oxford_v] No, the Gardaí don't, and I don't believe they did back in 1933 either. There are specialist armed units based in various locations around the country, but as a whole the force is unarmed.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 81769042@N00
comment._content: The 'Col Nelligan' referred to in The Times article has to be David Neligan - Michael Collins former 'spy in the Castle'... having spied for the IRA he went on to head Free State Army Intelligence during the Civil War - and subsequently headed up the DMP and founded the Special Branch. He would not have been flavour of the month in Republican circles when FF took power in 1932 - and was relieved of his position... don't know anything about the trial except from the pieces posted here - sounds like there could have been a political motivation behind it though... Here's the Wiki on him... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Neligan

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/81769042@N00] Sounds good alright - Neligan "had moved on in the meantime" presumably gelling with the time that he was transferred out into the Civil Service?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/81769042@N00] Ah. That explains why Colonel Neligan 'was sent on compulsory leave' in the words of court report.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: so sorry morrisoxfordV you didn't see uniformed Gardai wearing firearms unless they were a specialist firearms unit and there are very few of them about.  On the other side of the border the PSNI wear them all the time but the uniformed Garda on duty never carries a firearm.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/58894288@N07]Uniformed Gardaí did not wear firearms or carry them during the 80's so you never got directions from them, not anywhere within the Republic that is.  The RUC at that time did carry them and it was probably north of the border that you saw them.  The big debate on the specialist firearms units only took place since 2000 and the first units, who wear a more military style uniform with baseball cap were formed after 2002.

comment.author: 72311556@N00
comment._content: What started as a search for stylish vintage coats turned into an interesting history lesson. I really enjoyed reading the comments and getting more of the story to this picture! Fascinating!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Hi Carol, sorry I should have looked at the map sooner but I was enjoying the craic too much to worry about such things.  Wrong place, those are Greek Street flats and back on to the Bridewell Yard, there was a very famous foundry in the space in between them up to the '80's.  Chancery Street runs between the main Four Courts complex and the Bridewell and District Courts.  The L shaped building is the Bridewell and the toe of the L creates a confined yard where the prison vans back in to disgorge the prisoners from the stations and the Prisons and later to collect them at the end of the Court day.  The Prison Sergeants office is approx 1/3rd along the leg of the bar of the L!  Incidentally the strange object in the second window was probably an exhibit for a case as that room was used for storage of the registers of prisoners, charge sheets and exhibits.
